PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
The planned changes to improve safety at the Facility resolve the recommendations derived from the Process Hazard Analysis, as well as incorporate recommendations from compliance audits and incident investigations, as they become available. The Facility has a tracking system for implementing these recommendations and ensuring their closure. As required by the regulations, recommendations will be addressed and closed in a timely manner.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
Prior to the delivery date of this document, there have been no EPA RMP related accidents at the Lunday-Thagard Refinery in the past five (5) years. An incident investigation procedure is kept onsite which summarizes the required data to be reported in the RMP*submit printout, and will be utilized, as necessary to document any EPA RMP related incidents.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
Lunday-Thagard Refinery is located at 9302 Garfield, South Gate, California. The facility encompasses roughly 5 acres of land.  There are operations that occupy space on both east (9302) and west (9301) sides of Garfield Avenue.  
The primary business of the Lunday-Thagard Refinery is processing crude oils that produces finished asphalt and unfinished petroleum distillates.  The main operation is crude oil distillation.  The facility uses atmospheric distillation and vacuum distillation as the mean to physically separate the crude oil into fractions.  The present rated capacity of the refinery is 9.5 KBPD of crude.
The facility has developed a risk management program to address the EPA RMP requirements (40 CFR Part 68).  Lunday-Thagard Refinery is diligent in the handling of all chemicals and is dedicated to the safety of its employees and the neighboring community.  The Lunday-Thagard Refinery staff is trained and utilizes equipment to monitor the facility and provide safeguards, while effectively and safely distilling and storing the covered chemical, naphtha. 

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION POLICIES
Lunday-Thagard Refinery has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the covered processes.  Lunday-Thagard Refinery's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.
 
STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE
Lunday-Thagard Refinery processes crude oil and hence handles all the hydrocarbons that comprise crude oil.  Thus, there are hazardous substances that are utilized in or generated by the process. 
Based on the EPA definitions of flammable hydrocarbons, the quantities of the regulated flammable mixture in processing areas as well as at storage tanks at the facility consists of a TOTAL of 256,420 lbs

of Naphtha.  The facility has designated two Covered Processes associated with Naphtha.  They are as follows:
Naphtha Overhead Process 
The crude tower Naphtha Overhead process, consisting of Naphtha, includes approximately 18,000 lbs of inventory, and includes the crude tower overhead, a naphtha accumulator, a series of heat exchangers, and associated pumps and piping.
Naphtha Storage
Two atmospheric Naphtha storage tanks, each with a 20,000 gallon capacity, include an administrative control limiting the maximum inventory to 22 of the 24 ft height of the tanks (approximately 91.7%), which provide the ability to store a maximum of 119,210 lbs of Naphtha in each tank, for a total maximum inventory of 238,420 lbs of Naphtha.

Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary for Flammables
Scenario Description: After a preliminary evaluation of the naphtha at several locations, one worst-case release scenario was modeled which included a release of the Naphtha Storage Tank.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment - Flammables documentation behind the Hazard Assessment Tab in the Submittal Binder located at the facility. 
Alternative Release Scenarios Results Summary for Flammables
Scenario Description: One realistic alternative release scenario was modeled which considered a pipe shear.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment - Flammables documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment Tab in the Submittal Binder located at the facility. 
Risk Considerations
Although petroleum refining has inherent potential risks, and worst-case release scenarios can potentially reach the community; Lunday-Thagard Refinery has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst case type of event non-credible.
